channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [WFLY-1149] Naming lookup intermittently fails on IBM JDK due to org.jboss.remoting3.NotOpenException: Endpoint is not open.
item.description:
RemoteNamingTestCase intermittently fails when running on IBM JDK. According to logs the remoting channel had been closed before the endpoint tried to connect to it. Unfortunately, when I was trying to debug this issue the tests always nicely passed.

test.log snippet:

13:16:31,115 DEBUG [org.xnio.nio] (Remoting "config-based-naming-client-endpoint" read-1) Started channel thread 'Remoting "config-based-naming-client-endpoint" read-1', selector sun.nio.ch.EPollSelectorImpl@345642e1
 
13:16:31,115 DEBUG [org.xnio.nio] (Remoting "config-based-naming-client-endpoint" write-1) Started channel thread 'Remoting "config-based-naming-client-endpoint" write-1', selector sun.nio.ch.EPollSelectorImpl@1dc68cf2
 
13:16:31,121 DEBUG [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.InitialContextFactory] (main) jboss.naming.client.connect.options. has the following options {org.xnio.Options.SASL_POLICY_NOPLAINTEXT=>false}
 
13:16:31,191 ERROR [org.jboss.naming.remote.protocol.v1.RemoteNamingStoreV1] (Remoting "config-based-naming-client-endpoint" task-1) Channel end notification received, closing channel Channel ID d1f17196 (outbound) of Remoting connection fd3dcedc to /127.0.0.1:4447
 
13:16:31,204 DEBUG [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.HaRemoteNamingStore] (main) Failed to connect to server remote://127.0.0.1:4447: org.jboss.remoting3.NotOpenException: Endpoint is not open
 
	at org.jboss.remoting3.EndpointImpl.resourceUntick(EndpointImpl.java:182)
 
	at org.jboss.remoting3.EndpointImpl.doConnect(EndpointImpl.java:261)
 
	at org.jboss.remoting3.EndpointImpl.doConnect(EndpointImpl.java:251)
 
	at org.jboss.remoting3.EndpointImpl.connect(EndpointImpl.java:349)
 
	at org.jboss.remoting3.EndpointImpl.connect(EndpointImpl.java:333)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache$EndpointWrapper.connect(EndpointCache.java:105)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.HaRemoteNamingStore.failOverSequence(HaRemoteNamingStore.java:179)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.HaRemoteNamingStore.namingOperation(HaRemoteNamingStore.java:117)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.HaRemoteNamingStore.lookup(HaRemoteNamingStore.java:223)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.RemoteContext.lookup(RemoteContext.java:79)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.RemoteContext.lookup(RemoteContext.java:83)
 
	at javax.naming.InitialContext.lookup(InitialContext.java:422)
 
	at org.jboss.as.test.integration.naming.remote.simple.RemoteNamingTestCase.testRemoteLookup(RemoteNamingTestCase.java:74)

server.log snippet:

13:16:31,025 INFO  [org.jboss.as.server] (management-handler-thread - 3) JBAS018559: Deployed "test.jar"
 
13:16:31,163 DEBUG [org.jboss.naming.remote.server.RemoteNamingService] (Remoting "thinkpax" task-3) Channel Opened - Channel ID 51f17196 (inbound) of Remoting connection b9da2788 to /127.0.0.1:46866
 
13:16:31,176 DEBUG [org.jboss.naming.remote.server.RemoteNamingService] (Remoting "thinkpax" task-4) Chosen version 0x01
 
13:16:31,189 DEBUG [org.jboss.naming.remote.server.RemoteNamingService] (Remoting "thinkpax" read-1) Channel Channel ID 51f17196 (inbound) of Remoting connection b9da2788 to /127.0.0.1:46866 closed.
 
13:16:31,193 INFO  [org.jboss.as.naming] (Remoting "thinkpax" task-1) JBAS011806: Channel end notification received, closing channel Channel ID 51f17196 (inbound) of Remoting connection b9da2788 to null
item.summary: Naming lookup intermittently fails on IBM JDK due to org.jboss.remoting3.NotOpenException: Endpoint is not open.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
IBM JDK seems to be too fast. The culprit of this issue is that IBM JDK sometimes finalizes the InitialContext created by getRemoteContext() method before the lookup() method finishes. See the following log snippet. The RemoteContext is finalized by J9VMInternals.runFinalize and then lookup() method fails.

16:21:13,521 TRACE [org.jboss.remoting.resource] (Finalizer thread) my own stack trace from AbstractHandleableCloseable#closeAsync at ENTRY:
 
16:21:13,524 TRACE [org.jboss.remoting.resource] (Finalizer thread)  org.jboss.remoting3.spi.AbstractHandleableCloseable.closeAsync(AbstractHandleableCloseable.java:350)
 
16:21:13,529 TRACE [org.jboss.remoting.resource] (Finalizer thread)  org.jboss.remoting3.EndpointImpl.closeAction(EndpointImpl.java:208)
 
16:21:13,535 TRACE [org.jboss.remoting.resource] (Finalizer thread)  org.jboss.remoting3.spi.AbstractHandleableCloseable.closeAsync(AbstractHandleableCloseable.java:369)
 
16:21:13,539 TRACE [org.jboss.remoting.resource] (Finalizer thread)  org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache.release(EndpointCache.java:58)
 
16:21:13,543 TRACE [org.jboss.remoting.resource] (Finalizer thread)  org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache$EndpointWrapper.closeAsync(EndpointCache.java:189)
 
16:21:13,545 TRACE [org.jboss.remoting.resource] (Finalizer thread)  org.jboss.naming.remote.client.InitialContextFactory$1.close(InitialContextFactory.java:228)
 
16:21:13,555 TRACE [org.jboss.remoting.resource] (Finalizer thread)  org.jboss.naming.remote.client.RemoteContext.finalize(RemoteContext.java:199)
 
16:21:13,558 TRACE [org.jboss.remoting.resource] (Finalizer thread)  java.lang.J9VMInternals.runFinalize(J9VMInternals.java:455)
 
16:21:13,562 TRACE [org.jboss.remoting.resource] (Finalizer thread) Closing Remoting remote connection provider 50f78597 for endpoint "config-based-naming-client-endpoint" <e6872e7> asynchronously
 
16:21:13,570 TRACE [org.jboss.remoting.endpoint] (Finalizer thread) Phase 1 shutdown count 00000001 of endpoint "config-based-naming-client-endpoint" <e6872e7> (closed a cancelled connection)
 
16:21:13,571 TRACE [org.xnio.nio.selector] (Remoting "config-based-naming-client-endpoint" read-1) Beginning select on sun.nio.ch.EPollSelectorImpl@3e388ef1
 
16:21:13,574 TRACE [org.xnio.nio.selector] (Remoting "config-based-naming-client-endpoint" read-1) Selected on sun.nio.ch.EPollSelectorImpl@3e388ef1
 
16:21:13,576 TRACE [org.xnio.nio.selector] (Remoting "config-based-naming-client-endpoint" read-1) Beginning select on sun.nio.ch.EPollSelectorImpl@3e388ef1
 
16:21:13,575 DEBUG [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.HaRemoteNamingStore] (main) Failed to connect to server remote://127.0.0.1:4447: java.lang.RuntimeException: Operation failed with status CANCELLED
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.protocol.IoFutureHelper.get(IoFutureHelper.java:89)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.HaRemoteNamingStore.failOverSequence(HaRemoteNamingStore.java:180)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.HaRemoteNamingStore.namingStore(HaRemoteNamingStore.java:131)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.HaRemoteNamingStore.namingOperation(HaRemoteNamingStore.java:112)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.HaRemoteNamingStore.lookup(HaRemoteNamingStore.java:223)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.RemoteContext.lookup(RemoteContext.java:79)
 
	at org.jboss.naming.remote.client.RemoteContext.lookup(RemoteContext.java:83)
 
	at javax.naming.InitialContext.lookup(InitialContext.java:422)
 
	at org.jboss.as.test.integration.naming.remote.simple.RemoteNamingTestCase.testRemoteLookup(RemoteNamingTestCase.java:77)

The current test method which does not work on IBM JDK is as follows:

    @Test public void testRemoteLookup() throws Exception {
 
        assertEquals("TestValue", getRemoteContext().lookup("test"));
 
    }

And this is a slightly modified test method which works on IBM JDK nicely (it holds an explicit reference to the InitialContext):

    @Test public void testRemoteLookup() throws Exception {
 
        Context context = null;
 
        try {
 
            context = getRemoteContext();
 
            assertEquals("TestValue", context.lookup("test"));
 
        } finally {
 
            if (context != null)
 
                context.close();
 
        }
 
    }

Note that the issue disappears when running with any Byteman's script, i.e. it is not possible to debug it with Byteman. That's the reason why I had to modify the remoting sources to print out a stack trace on closeAsync method entry.

When this fails, is it ever the first test executed that fails, or is it always the 2nd or third?

I'm concerned this patch is covering over a race condition.

If you look at your trace logging, you can see that the DEBUG stack trace shows the javax.naming.InitialContext has a ref to the RemoteContext. The test execution stack has a reference to the InitialContext, even without your patch. This is sufficient to keep the RemoteContext from being gc'd, unless the JVM is fundamentally broken (unlikely in the extreme.)

The patch creating a local variable reference to the RemoteContext is just another form of reference on the stack and shouldn't be preventing the RemoteContext being gc'd, since it shouldn't be gc'd anyway.

I suspect what the patch is really doing that solves the intermittent failure is calling context.close(). That means each test method is cleaning up the context. I'm concerned what was happening before is a race condition. Test method #1 uses a RemoteContext, and then it gets closed by the gc. There's a race with the next test method #2 creating a new RemoteContext using the same underlying endpoint (which is cached and would be reused by the 2nd test if the 1st hasn't cleaned up yet.) Looking at the code in RemoteContext EndpointCache I don't see how this could happen though.

Thanks for the comment, Brian. I did my patch on closeAsync method just to see who/what is closing the remoting connection on the client side, i.e. to be able to see it is JVM finalizer. Trace logs only shows that a closing request was sent from client.

I am not sure if it really is a race condition between two test methods as it is failing even when only one test method is executed (-Dtest=RemoteNamingTestCase#testRemoteLookup). Furthermore, it is the first test method which fails when all test methods are executed. Sometimes also the second method fails, but the third method usually passes, at least on IBM JDK6. On IBM JDK7 all of them regularly fail.

I retested it again several times without 'context.close()' and it worked nicely on my laptop, so it looks like the local variable reference fixing this. It is weird, I know. Also note that this issue affects IBM JDKs only. I have not seen it on Oracle/Open JDK.

It is even more weird. A passes, but B fails, see below.

A

 
    public void testRemoteLookup() throws Exception {
 
        Context context = getRemoteContext();
 
        assertEquals("TestValue", context.lookup("test"));
 
        context.toString();
 
    }

B

 
    public void testRemoteLookup() throws Exception {
 
        Context context = getRemoteContext();
 
        assertEquals("TestValue", context.lookup("test"));
 
    }

I am now trying to compare byte code of those two generated by IBM JDK7 as Carlo suggested.

Nothing interesting in byte code between A and B, see the bold part below. And byte code generated by Oracle JDK is the same as byte code generated by IBM JDK, there is no difference. Also disabling JIT did not help.

public void testRemoteLookup() throws java.lang.Exception;
Code:
0: aload_0
1: invokevirtual #29 // Method getRemoteContext)Ljavax/naming/Context;
4: astore_1
5: ldc #30 // String TestValue
7: aload_1
8: ldc #31 // String test
10: invokeinterface #32, 2 // InterfaceMethod javax/naming/Context.lookup:(Ljava/lang/String;)Ljava/lang/Object;
15: invokestatic #33 // Method org/junit/Assert.assertEquals:(Ljava/lang/Object;Ljava/lang/Object;)V
18: aload_1
19: invokevirtual #34 // Method java/lang/Object.toString)Ljava/lang/String;
22: pop
23: return
With '-verbose:gc' the issue disappears as well.

Very weird indeed!

Since the problem is fixed without having to call context.close(), then I'm not concerned about our code, particularly since the problem occurs when only 1 test method is executed. Last night I looked very carefully at our InitialContextFactory/RemoteContext/NamingStoreCache/EndpointCache/HaRemoteNamingStore to look for a race conditions or a way the Endpoint could leak out and get closed inappropriately and I found nothing.

I just can't see what could cause this. The cache access is all synchronized, it should not be possible for the finalizer to close an active endpoint, as the reference count should have been increased by this point.

Can you add some trace logging to EndpointCache and have a look at what is going on? In particular at every call to get and release it would be good to see the endpoint object, the reference count, and the stack trace?
Stuart, I will try that. The finalize method, however, is called on RemoteContext, so it should be the RemoteContext which has lost references... I don't understand what happens there.
The endpoint is shared between multiple remote contexts. If all remote contexts are finalised then the Endpoint will be closed and a new one created on the next connection.

Another note which might not be related to this issue: I've noticed the javadoc of InitialContextFactory#getInitialContext(Hashtable<?,?> environment) says:

The environment parameter is owned by the caller.
The implementation will not modify the object or keep a reference
to it, although it may keep a reference to a clone or copy.

The implementation of RemoteContext, however, keeps a reference to the environment parameter without copying/cloning it (line 71). Is it correct?
The environment parameter is cloned in the constructor of InitialContext actually, so it seems to be alright.

I've added more trace logging to the EndpointCache as follows:

diff --git a/src/main/java/org/jboss/naming/remote/client/EndpointCache.java b/src/main/java/org/jboss/naming/remote/client/EndpointCache.java
 
index be369b7..ee3ce13 100644
 
--- a/src/main/java/org/jboss/naming/remote/client/EndpointCache.java
 
+++ b/src/main/java/org/jboss/naming/remote/client/EndpointCache.java
 
@@ -47,11 +47,33 @@ public class EndpointCache {
 
             cache.putIfAbsent(endpointHash, cacheEntry);
 
         }
 
         cacheEntry.referenceCount.incrementAndGet();
 
+
 
+        logger.info("==============================");
 
+        logger.info("EndpointCache.get()");
 
+        logger.infof("cacheEntry.endpoint = %s", cacheEntry.endpoint);
 
+        logger.infof("cacheEntry.referenceCount = %s", cacheEntry.referenceCount.get());
 
+        logger.info("stack trace:");
 
+        for (StackTraceElement ste : new Throwable().getStackTrace()) {
 
+            logger.infof("===== \t %s", ste);
 
+        }
 
+        logger.info("==============================");
 
+
 
         return cacheEntry.endpointWrapper;
 
     }
 
 
     public synchronized void release(final CacheKey endpointHash, final boolean async) {
 
         final CacheEntry cacheEntry = cache.get(endpointHash);
 
+
 
+        logger.info("------------------------------");
 
+        logger.info("EndpointCache.release()");
 
+        logger.infof("cacheEntry.endpoint = %s", cacheEntry.endpoint);
 
+        logger.infof("cacheEntry.referenceCount = %s", cacheEntry.referenceCount.get());
 
+        logger.info("stack trace:");
 
+        for (StackTraceElement ste : new Throwable().getStackTrace()) {
 
+            logger.infof("===== \t %s", ste);
 
+        }
 
+        logger.info("------------------------------");
 
+
 
         if (cacheEntry.referenceCount.decrementAndGet() == 0) {
 
             try {
 
                 if (async) {

Here is the snippet from test log output:

12:22:35,244 INFO  [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache] (Finalizer thread) ------------------------------
 
12:22:35,246 INFO  [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache] (Finalizer thread) EndpointCache.release()
 
12:22:35,248 INFO  [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache] (Finalizer thread) cacheEntry.endpoint = endpoint "config-based-naming-client-endpoint" <c825c546>
 
12:22:35,251 INFO  [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache] (Finalizer thread) cacheEntry.referenceCount = 1
 
12:22:35,254 INFO  [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache] (Finalizer thread) stack trace:
 
12:22:35,257 INFO  [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache] (Finalizer thread) ===== 	 org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache.release(EndpointCache.java:72)
 
12:22:35,262 INFO  [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache] (Finalizer thread) ===== 	 org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache$EndpointWrapper.closeAsync(EndpointCache.java:211)
 
12:22:35,265 INFO  [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache] (Finalizer thread) ===== 	 org.jboss.naming.remote.client.InitialContextFactory$1.close(InitialContextFactory.java:228)
 
12:22:35,268 INFO  [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache] (Finalizer thread) ===== 	 org.jboss.naming.remote.client.RemoteContext.finalize(RemoteContext.java:199)
 
12:22:35,271 INFO  [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache] (Finalizer thread) ===== 	 java.lang.J9VMInternals.runFinalize(J9VMInternals.java:455)
 
12:22:35,273 INFO  [org.jboss.naming.remote.client.EndpointCache] (Finalizer thread) ------------------------------

See the attached full test log - test_output_with_trace_logging_in_EndpointCache.xml.

This is really weird, it really does look like an active object is being finalized.

Can you add some logging in lookup, the constructor, and finalise() of RemoteNamingStore? And add a finalised flag, and log a message if lookup is called after the object is finalized?

This really seems unlikely to me, as I would expect pretty much everything to be broken, but I really can't see anything else that could be happening.

Stuart, I think you were looking for logging from RemoteContext, not RemoteNamingStore.

In any logging added to RemoteContext, please include the toString() output of the RemoteContext so we see its identity hashcode and can track the instance.

I will add more logging into it. The finalization often happens during the execution of HaRemoteNamingStore.java:180 which is:

connection = IoFutureHelper.get(futureConnection, connectionInfo.getConnectionTimeout(), TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS);

In that case it ends with 'Operation failed with status CANCELLED' as shown in previous logs above.
Sometimes the finalization also hits HaRemoteNamingStore.java:179 and then it ends up with 'org.jboss.remoting3.NotOpenException: Endpoint is not open' as shown in the first logs of this jira.

Here are new logs, see endpoint_is_not_open_2012-11-26.xml and failed_with_status_cancelled_2012-11-26.xml attached to this jira.

The relevant patch of jboss-remote-naming can be seen at
http://pastebin.test.redhat.com/117046

When trying a patch like the following one (see finally clause there) the issue again disappears.

@@ -73,10 +80,17 @@ public class RemoteContext implements Context, NameParser {
 
     }
 
 
     public Object lookup(final Name name) throws NamingException {
 
+        log.info("entering RemoteContext#lookup(), instance " + this);
 
+        log.info(this + "#finalized = " + finalized);
 
         if (isEmpty(name)) {
 
             return new RemoteContext(prefix, namingStore, environment);
 
         }
 
-        return namingStore.lookup(getAbsoluteName(name));
 
+        try {
 
+            return namingStore.lookup(getAbsoluteName(name));
 
+        } finally {
 
+            log.info("RemoteContext#lookup finally clause, instance " + this);
 
+            log.info(this + "#finalized = " + finalized);
 
+        }
 
     }
 
 
     public Object lookup(final String name) throws NamingException {

Wow, according to those logs the RemoteContext is finalized while there is a reference to it on the stack.

Only 1 instance is ever created (which we can say for sure as there is logging in the constructor), it is finalized, then several hundred ms later the stack trace shows that the instance is still on the stack.

We probably need to take this up with IBM.

Of course it is possible I am reading this wrong, but it looks pretty conclusive to me, and is backed up by the circumstantial evidence. If anyone else wants to provide a second opinion that would be appreciated.

Both of those logs show the RemoteContext that is used for the lookup() call also being finalized. I think IBM has a bug.

You've now made 2 changes to code that result in a local variable ref to an object being needed for use on the operand stack a bit longer, and both result in the object no longer being garbage collected. Your patch to the test case does that by requiring use of local variable 1 in

18: aload_1
19: invokevirtual #34 // Method java/lang/Object.toString)Ljava/lang/String;

and your finally block in RemoteContext.lookup() will have a similar effect with local variable 0 (this). Even more amazing, the two changes affect refs to different objects (InitialContext vs RemoteContext).

If looking at a timing issue and the logs do not look as you would expect I would double check we are not using asynchronous logging - from my previous role I remember Galder having some problems debugging clustering issues where the ordering and timing of log messages was not as expected.

Luckily in this case the timing issues are quite clear. There are 3 basic events – construct, lookup, finalize – with the first two done on one thread and the 3rd on another. Logically, the 3rd has to follow the 1st, and does in the logs. The logs show the 3rd happening in the middle of execution of the 2nd. We know that reported timing is essentially accurate, because the 3rd is producing side effects (closing the endpoint) that result in failure of the 2nd.

Once the constructor executes there is a reference chain leading back to a variable on the stack that should be sufficient to keep the RemoteContext from being gc'd.
I will try to isolate it into a simple test case which then can be used for filing a bug against IBM JDK.

Just stating the obvious here, which may or may not change the results. The logs shows that you are using:

<property value="pxa6470sr2-20120901_01 (SR2)" name="java.runtime.version"/>

There's a SR3 JDK update available http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/java/jdk/aix/j764/Java7_64.fixinfo.html which you might want to try reproducing against, before reporting it to IBM, if it's reproducible in that version.
Thanks, Jaikiran, I will try that.

The issue also affects IBM JDK7 SR3.
And as mentioned in the Environment field, IBM JDK6 is affected too.
I tried to use -Xtgc: and -Xtrace: settings of IBM JDK, but with no luck. I have not reached to any clue why the finalize method is triggered on the RemoteContext.

However, it is possible to invoke this issue with jboss-remote-naming unit tests as well.

See FinalizerTest at
https://github.com/istudens/jboss-remote-naming/compare/AS7-5967

I've posted it to IBM forum:

https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=463851

It seems it is not considered being a bug, see
https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/forums/thread.jspa?messageID=14914414&#14914414

I vote that when jboss-remote-naming requires JDK 7 we get rid of the finalize() implementation with the expectation that users will use try-with-resource. Until then, this is a known issue and users are advised to close their InitialContext in a finally block the way you did in your testsuite patch. That's the right thing to do anyway.

BTW, if you all agree with my suggestion, we should probably leave this JIRA open. Just fix the test so it's reliable and reword the JIRA title a bit to something like "Naming lookup intermittently fails on IBM JDK due to org.jboss.remoting3.NotOpenException: Endpoint is not open."
I agree with Brian.

A link that appeared on the ibm forum:
https://www.securecoding.cert.org/confluence/display/java/MET12-J.+Do+not+use+finalizers
I cannot re-open the pull requests. Shall I create them again?

I cannot re-open the pull requests. Shall I create them again?

I've re-opened them. You can update them appropriately.
Done. I've just rebased them.
Leaving this jira unassigned and open.

I think that the actual finalize method is on the wrong object. (Or the close tasks tied to the wrong object).

The RemoteContext goes out of use early in the game, while other objects are still in use. So essentially each object should govern its own lifecycle properly and not let it be governed by an aggregate.
Carlo de Wolf <cdewolf@redhat.com> made a comment on bug 901231
Carlo de Wolf <cdewolf@redhat.com> made a comment on bug 901231
Carlo de Wolf <cdewolf@redhat.com> made a comment on bug 901231

Ivo Studensky <istudens@redhat.com> made a comment on bug 901231

The relevant jiras are public so this BZ should be public as well.

Stuart Douglas <sdouglas@redhat.com> made a comment on bug 901231

Unfortunatly there is not really any way to tell if a given finalizer will cause problems.

I think that the best we can do is have a system property (-Dbroken.ibm.garbage.collection=true), and in the finalisers check for the presense of this property and if it is present don't perform the finalization action.

Jimmy Wilson <jawilson@redhat.com> made a comment on bug 901231

@Stuart: If this is the only way to address this, is a new property necessary? There are standard JVM properties that we could use to identify an IBM JVM and then act accordingly? Are there any IBM JVMs without this issue? My understanding is that all of them have it.

Stuart Douglas <sdouglas@redhat.com> made a comment on bug 901231

It is possible that we have existing customers running the IBM JDK that are not experiencing this issue that will start to experience resource leaks if we disable these finalisers.

Hi Ivo,

Can you give this patch a try?

https://github.com/n1hility/jboss-remote-naming/commit/3f9ee91e6277f77225d43879867cc30bd068bb81
There was a type-o in my patch in the way it detects the IBM VM that Brian noticed. I take it this is without fixing that?

You need this change to fix the type-o:
https://github.com/n1hility/jboss-remote-naming/commit/717a0c425528e24c60a547adc1322c494fadacb6
Yep, it was running without that fix. I've rerun it, so you can see results soon at the same place.
The complete and correct fix, which can affect non-IBM JVMS has been submitted as a PR.
Kabir Khan <kkhan@redhat.com> changed the Status of bug 923836 from NEW to MODIFIED
Paul Gier <pgier@redhat.com> changed the Status of bug 923836 from MODIFIED to ON_QA
Jan Martiska <jmartisk@redhat.com> changed the Status of bug 923836 from ON_QA to VERIFIED
